required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Delivery Decisions in Extreme Prematurity: Evaluating Decisional Regret

brief_summary.textblock: The anticipated birth of an extremely low gestational age infant presents many complex and ethically challenging questions, including whether to initiate resuscitation or comfort care after delivery. Failure to identify and align decision-making to parents' values during periviabilty counseling may result in greater opportunity for decisional regret. The goal of the proposed research is to assess decisional regret in mothers of extremely premature births and to compare decisional regret in mothers who chose resuscitation at time of delivery to those who chose comfort care. Approximately 1000 mothers of infants born extremely premature at 2 perinatal centers in the US will be surveyed.

primary_outcome.description: To assess decisional regret in mothers of extremely premature liveborn infants.
Comparison of decisional regret in mothers who chose resuscitation versus mothers who chose comfort care at the time of delivery.

secondary_outcome.measure: Define characteristics associated with decisional regret
secondary_outcome.description: Identify characteristics, and specifically potentially modifiable characteristics, that are associated with decisional regret in our population of mothers.

study_pop.textblock: The study population will consist of mothers who delivered infants between 22 and 25 completed weeks gestation during the study timeframe at one of two US perinatal centers.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Mothers of infants born between 22 and 25 completed weeks gestation during the study timeframe.
- Mothers who had a documented perinatal consult
- Greater than 18 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Potential life limiting fetal diagnoses aside from prematurity and non-English primary language

eligibility.gender_description: Gender eligibility for this study will be determined by women who had the ability to become pregnant and give birth at one of 2 perinatal centers.
